isis.stitle: ELECTRICAL SYSTEM TROUBLESHOOTING GUIDE / 9200 9300 9400 MODELS BUILT AFTER JANUARY 1, 1995 - SPEEDOMETER/TACHOMETER DIAGNOSTICS AND SERVICE - PROGRAMMING - 9600, 9700 MODELS

svcsubproc.title: January 1989 to January 1991 - All Engines
svcsubproc.para: Speedometer and tachometer DIP switches are located on the rear of each gauge ( Figure 20). The DIP switches are set to match each vehicle component configuration.

The speedometer original DIP switch settings are shown on the vehicle linesetting ticket in the 010000 code, Speedo - last ten (10) digits ( Figure 16) The DIP switch settings can also be determined by following the DIP Switch Configuration
section.

Any changes in vehicle components like tire size or axle ratio require recalibration of the ten (10) speedometer switches. The prop shaft revolutions per mile must be calculated and the DIP switches physically set. Refer to PROGRAMMING, CALCULATION AND SWITCH SETTING
.

Replacing the speedometer or tachometer requires that ALL DIP switches be physically set to match the settings of the gauge being removed. The original DIP switch settings can be found on the vehicle linesetting ticket.

Speedometer and tachometer DIP switch settings can also be determined by following the DIP Switch Configuration
section.

- Programming the speedometer DIP switches involves setting the ten (10) switches to positions based on the revolutions per mile of the propeller shaft. Refer to PROGRAMMING, CALCULATION AND SWITCH SETTING
.

DIP Switch Configuration - Tachometer - The ten (10) DIP switch positions are for programming the tachometer RPM settings. These settings are based on engine model and flywheel gear teeth per revolution as shown in the Tachometer DIP Switch Settings Chart
.

svcsubproc.title: January 1991 to January 1994 - All Engines
svcsubproc.para: The speedo/tach cluster has two sets of DIP switches with ten switches in each bank. The DIP switches are located at the top, rear of the cluster and can be used to manually program speedo/tach module information ( Figure 21).

important.para: The original speedo/tach cluster microprocessor is electronically programmed, when the vehicle is built, to match the component configuration of the vehicle. However, the physical positions of all the DIP switches remain in the "0" position.

svcsubproc.para:
The original electronically programmed settings are shown on the vehicle linesetting ticket in the 010000 code, Speedo & Misc - last twenty (20) digits ( Figure 22). DIP switch settings can also be determined by following the DIP Switch Configuration
section.

important.para:
Physically moving any of the DIP switches from the "0" position disables all of the electronically programmed settings of the cluster. If any DIP switch is moved for any reason, then ALL of the DIP switches must be physically moved to the appropriate positions shown on the vehicle linesetting ticket or determined by following the DIP Switch Configuration
section. Physically moving all the DIP switches back to the "0" position of an electronically programmed cluster will enable the original programmed settings.

svcsubproc.para:
Any changes in vehicle components like tire size or axle ratio requires recalibration of the ten (10) speedometer switches. The prop shaft revolutions per mile must be calculated and the DIP switches physically set. Refer to PROGRAMMING, CALCULATION AND SWITCH SETTING
.

note.para:
Physically setting the new DIP switch positions for the speedometer disables all of the electronically programmed settings. This requires that the tachometer and odometer switches also be physically set. These settings can be found on the vehicle linesetting ticket or determined by following the DIP Switch Configuration
section.

svcsubproc.para: Replacing the speedo/tach cluster requires that the new module be manually programmed by physically setting all DIP switches to match the vehicle component configuration.
The original electronically programmed DIP switch settings are found on the vehicle linesetting ticket, or can be determined by following the DIP Switch Configuration section below.

- Programming the speedometer involves setting the ten (10) DIP switches to positions based on the revolutions per mile of the propeller shaft. Refer to PROGRAMMING, CALCULATION AND SWITCH SETTING
.

DIP Switch Configuration - Tachometer - The first eight (8) DIP switch positions on the right bank are for programming the tachometer RPM settings. These settings are based on engine model and flywheel gear teeth per revolution as shown in the Tachometer DIP Switch Settings Chart
.
Switch number 9 is not active - Set at "0"

DIP Switch Configuration - Odometer - The number ten (10) switch on the right bank is for setting the odometer to show either miles or kilometers. This switch must be set to "0" for miles, or "1" for kilometers.

entry.para: No. of Teeth on Flywheel Ring Gear
Detroit Diesel Series 60 With No. 1 Flywheel Housing
Detroit Diesel Series 60 With Auto. Trans. and No. 2 Flywheel Housing
#IMPORTANT: The rightmost switch of the tachometer DIP switches (#10) is for selecting odometer mode-position "0" is for miles and position "1" is for kilometers.

svcsubproc.title: January 1994 and Later - Mechanical Engines
svcsubproc.para: The speedo/tach cluster has two sets of DIP switches with ten switches in each bank. The DIP switches are located at the top, rear of the cluster and can be used to manually program speedo/tach module information ( Figure 21).

important.para: The original speedo/tach cluster microprocessor is electronically programmed, when the vehicle is built, to match the component configuration of the vehicle. However, the physical positions of all the DIP switches remain in the "0" position.

svcsubproc.para:
The original electronically programmed settings are shown on the vehicle linesetting ticket in the 010000 code, Speedo & Misc - last twenty (20) digits ( Figure 22). DIP switch settings can also be determined by following the DIP Switch Configuration
section.

important.para:
Physically moving any of the DIP switches from the "0" position disables all of the electronically programmed settings of the cluster. If any DIP switch is moved for any reason, then ALL of the DIP switches must be physically moved to the appropriate positions shown on the vehicle linesetting ticket or determined by following the DIP Switch Configuration
section. Physically moving all the DIP switches back to the "0" position of an electronically programmed cluster will enable the original programmed settings.

svcsubproc.para:
Any changes in vehicle components like tire size or axle ratio requires recalibration of the 10 speedometer switches. The prop shaft revolutions per mile must be calculated and the DIP switches physically set. Refer to PROGRAMMING, CALCULATION AND SWITCH SETTING
.

note.para:
Physically setting the new DIP switch positions for the speedometer disables all of the electronically programmed settings. This requires that the tachometer and odometer switches also be physically set. These settings can be found on the vehicle linesetting ticket or determined by following the DIP Switch Configuration
section.

svcsubproc.para: Replacing the speedo/tach cluster requires that the new module be manually programmed by physically setting all DIP switches to match the vehicle component configuration.
The original electronically programmed DIP switch settings are found on the vehicle linesetting ticket, or can be determined by following the DIP Switch Configuration section below.

- Programming the speedometer involves setting the ten (10) DIP switches to positions based on the revolutions per mile of the propeller shaft. Refer to PROGRAMMING, CALCULATION AND SWITCH SETTING
.

DIP Switch Configuration - Tachometer - The first eight (8) DIP switch positions on the right bank are for programming the tachometer RPM settings. These settings are based on engine model and flywheel gear teeth per revolution as shown in the Tachometer DIP Switch Settings Chart
.
Switch number 9 is not active - Set at "0"

DIP Switch Configuration - Odometer - The number ten (10) switch on the right bank is for setting the odometer to show either miles or kilometers. This switch must be set to "0" for miles, or "1" for kilometers.

svcsubproc.title: January 1994 to November 1997 - Electronic Engines
svcsubproc.para: The speedo/tach cluster has two sets of DIP switches with ten switches in each bank. The DIP switches are located at the top, rear of the cluster and can be used to manually program the speedo/tach microprocessor to receive data link signals generated by the engine Electronic Control Module (ECM) ( Figure 21).
Information on engine, axle ratio, tire revolutions per mile, number of teeth on the transmission speedometer gear, etc. are programmed into the engine ECM and not the speedo/tach module.

important.para: The original speedo/tach cluster microprocessor is electronically programmed, when the vehicle is built, to receive data link signals generated by the engine ECM. However, the physical positions of all the DIP switches remain in the "0" position.

svcsubproc.para:
The original electronically programmed settings are shown on the vehicle linesetting ticket in the 010000 code, Speedo & Misc - last twenty (20) digits ( Figure 22). DIP switch settings can also be determined by following the DIP Switch Configuration
section.

important.para:
Physically moving any of the DIP switches from the "0" position disables all of the electronically programmed settings of the cluster. If any DIP switch is moved for any reason, then ALL of the DIP switches must be physically moved to the appropriate positions shown on the vehicle linesetting ticket or determined by following the DIP Switch Configuration
section. Physically moving all the DIP switches back to the "0" position of an electronically programmed cluster will enable the original programmed settings.

svcsubproc.para: If there are any changes in vehicle components, such as tire size or axle ratio etc., the engine ECM must be reprogrammed with the correct data.

note.para: The speedo/tach module microprocessor or DIP switches do not get reprogrammed.

svcsubproc.para: The Pro-Link 9000 Electronic Service Tool (EST), or the EZ-Tech with the authorized engine manufacturer's software must be used for reprogramming the engine ECM. Refer to the Pro-Link 9000 manual or the engine manufacturer's service literature for instructions.
If a cluster is to be replaced, the service cluster must be programmed either electronically or manually.

note.para: An electronic service tool (EST) such as the Pro-Link 9000 with the Instrument Panel Cartridge Kit, or the EZ-Tech with the instrument cluster software, are used to program the speedometer/tachometer module microprocessor, through the J1708 data link . Refer to the Pro-Link or EZ-Tech instrument cluster software manual for instructions. This method requires that all of the DIP switches be physically set in the "0" position.

svcsubproc.para: If manually programming the cluster, the DIP switches should be physically set to the positions shown on the vehicle linesetting ticket or can be determined by following the DIP Switch Configuration section below.
The physical settings of the DIP switch positions for these engines is as follows:
Ten Speedometer Switches - 1111111111 (All ten (10) positions on left bank).
Eight Tachometer Switches - 11111111 (First eight (8) positions on right bank).
Switch number 9 is not active - 0.
One Odometer Switch - 0 or 1 (Number 10 on right bank) "0" for miles or "1" for kilometers.
